snippet: A fight over $3.4 billion in retroactive pay for teachers could make it harder for other city workers to win the raises they have been agitating for after several years of working with expired contracts.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is entering final stages of overlooked and drawn-out battle with United Federation of Teachers over $3.4 billion in retroactive pay; victory for teachers' union could make it harder for other municipal unions to win raises and back pay they seek following years of working with expired contracts; dispute will turn on findings of state-appointed panel whose recommendations are expected within next few months.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and KATE TAYLOR

lead_paragraph: A fight over $3.4 billion in retroactive pay for teachers could make it harder for other city workers to win the raises they have been agitating for after several years of working with expired contracts.

headline.main: Teachers’ Push for Back Pay May Pinch New York City
headline.print_headline: Teachers’ Push for Back Pay May Pinch City
